body: @franz1981 PTAL... I think this might be related to a change of yours
The `StringUtil.decodeHexNibble(hex[0 + 3])` call will be `StringUtil.decodeHexNibble(32)` which returns `-1`. Forgot to mention that above.

mmm I don't follow it sorry...
@lars-n are you able to make this to be triggered by actual HTTP data?
The comment I've left for myself of the future (i.e. today)
```
byte[] is produced by LineParse::parseLine that already skip ISO CTRL and Whitespace chars
```
means that there's no need to check for whitespaces because are already checked upfront
i.e. https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/3de03282d558d7b7e2c282b31db73335f0f498b1/codec-http/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http/HttpObjectDecoder.java#L1123
that's been used by `HttpObjectDecoder::skipControlChars` and is populated by both white spaces and CTRL chars
I'm beginning to wonder if the server I'm querying is returning crap data. Maybe pause for now while I'll try to verify that.

What I've noticed is that we receive two types of responses from that server (output from curl). The failing one is the first which is `chunked`.

Fails:

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Transfer-Encoding: chunked
< Content-Type: text/xml; charset=UTF-8
< Server: Microsoft-IIS/10.0
< X-Powered-By: ASP.NET
< Date: Mon, 13 Mar 2023 16:47:44 GMT
< Set-Cookie: NSC_wTfswfs_c2cjoufhsbujpo=ffffffff099b5f1f45525d5f4f58455e445a4a42378b;expires=Mon, 13-Mar-2023 16:58:25 GMT;path=/;secure;httponly
```

This works (because it won't go via the getChunkedSize method):

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Content-Type: text/xml; charset=UTF-8
< Server: Microsoft-IIS/10.0
< X-Powered-By: ASP.NET
< Date: Mon, 13 Mar 2023 16:48:04 GMT
< Content-Length: 3819
< Set-Cookie: NSC_wTfswfs_c2cjoufhsbujpo=ffffffff099b5f1f45525d5f4f58455e445a4a42378b;expires=Mon, 13-Mar-2023 16:58:45 GMT;path=/;secure;httponly
``` 

The string `"BDC Cookie: NSC_wTfswfs_c2cjoufhsbujpo=ffffffff099b5f1f45525d5f4f58455e445a4a42378b;expires=Mon, 13-Mar-2023 14:16:06 GMT;path=/;secure;httponly";` I used in the example above is the actual data from reading a chunked response like the ones above.

@franz1981 , had a look at the code around `SKIP_CONTROL_CHARS_BYTES` you mentioned. The case where is breaks is for `32` which, correct me if I'm wrong, would not be skipped by that code? I think `32` is a whitespace in ASCII. 

In my example `BDC Cook` the whitespace's value when reading `hex[start+i] ` is `32`.

Maybe as some additional input:

```
byte[] data = new byte[] {57, 32, 57}; // data like this ends up in the getChunkedSize method, can't tell why it ends up there
System.out.println(new String(data)); // "9 9"
System.out.println(Character.isWhitespace(data[1])); // true, this was used in the previous implementation of the getChunkedSize method
System.out.println(StringUtil.decodeHexNibble(data[1])); // -1
```
Yeah, the part I don't understand is the skipping, tbh, that should have worked. Will take a look

issue.title: Chunked HTTP length decoding should account for whitespaces/ctrl chars (Fixes #13273)

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

#12321 introduces the assumption that whitespaces/ctrl chars are already stripped out hex chars of HTTP chunk length. It was a wrong assumption.

Modifications:

Correctly check for whitespace and ctrl chars and re-introduce whitespace (leading) trim

Result:

Fixes #13273

body: Thanks @lars-n for the hints, I've sent https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/13274, if you can take a look and try it would be great

Is this the line that should be dropping the whitespace? https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/4.1/codec-http/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http/HttpObjectDecoder.java#L1085

In my case `skipControlChars` isn't called because `currentState` is set to `READ_CHUNK_SIZE` and so `currentState == State.SKIP_CONTROL_CHARS` evals to `false`. But again, really not familiar with the code here.

Sadly it doesn't drop the white space but stop the very first char that's not a white space instead.
In the pr I have fixed the comment to better understand it next time.
@lars-n let me know if this work for you, it is now working as the previous version, but faster

Thanks for the quick response.

And a dumb question, is there a simple way for me to test this, except building netty myself?

Mmmm probably not a fast one, sadly :(
I have added few tests covering your (and others) test cases but these are not end 2 end tests
